results.headline: Review: ‘When the Bough Breaks,’ Blame a Scary Pregnancy Surrogate
results.summary_short: This movie, about a well-off couple and the woman they hire to carry their embryo, looks for suspense in a genre that has little left.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When the Bough Breaks

results.headline: Review: In ‘Kicks,’ the Promise (and Perils) of Those Air Jordans
results.summary_short: This debut feature depicts a 15-year-old in a tough neighborhood who buys the shoes of his dreams — and the desperation he feels when they are taken from him.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kicks

results.headline: Review: In ‘Demon,’ Wedding Jitters From the Uninvited Dead
results.summary_short: A modern ghost story haunted by the Holocaust, this film by the Polish director Marcin Wrona reconceptualizes the Jewish mythology of the dybbuk.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Demon

results.headline: Review: In ‘As I Open My Eyes,’ Feeling a Revolution Coming
results.summary_short: A headstrong singer comes of age on the eve of Tunisia’s Jasmine Revolution.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As I Open My Eyes

results.headline: Review: In ‘Cameraperson,’ a Found Poem Filtered Through an Intent Eye
results.summary_short: Kirsten Johnson’s riveting documentary flits from Bosnia to Darfur to ground zero and zigzags across time, prompting reflection on the nature of her art.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cameraperson

results.headline: Review: 5 Murdered Prostitutes and an Anxious City in ‘London Road’
results.summary_short: A spate of real-life murders in England in 2006 form the basis of this film directed by Rufus Norris.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of London Road

results.headline: Review: Sully Landed the Plane. Then He Had to Endure the Spotlight.
results.summary_short: “Sully,” Clint Eastwood’s film about US Airways Flight 1549, largely involves what happens after he, his crew and his passengers are plucked from the Hudson.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sully

results.headline: Review: ‘Starving the Beast’ Traces the Burdens of Higher Education Defunding
results.summary_short: This documentary by Steve Mims describes an ideological war over public higher education that is being conducted state by state.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starving the Beast

results.headline: Review: ‘Defying the Nazis’: An American Couple on a Rescue Mission
results.summary_short: Ken Burns and Artemis Joukowsky’s documentary tells of Waitstill and Martha Sharp, who traveled to Czechoslovakia in 1939 to help Jews and others flee persecution.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Defying the Nazis

results.headline: Review: ‘Author: The JT Leroy Story’ Renders a Literary Charlatan
results.summary_short: Jeff Feuerzeig’s documentary charts the invention of an underage H.I.V.-positive hustler, and how the famous and nonfamous were taken in until the hoax was exposed.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Author: The JT Leroy Story

results.headline: Review: ‘Brother Nature’: Fish Out of Water With the Future In-Laws
results.summary_short: Taran Killam and Bobby Moynihan of “Saturday Night Live” are among the cast in an unfunny comedy set in the woods.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brother Nature

results.headline: Review: In ‘Ithaca,’ Meg Ryan and Tom Hanks Reunite for a War Story
results.summary_short: In this adaptation of William Saroyan’s “The Human Comedy,” a young bicycle messenger delivers telegrams to families during the tumultuous World War II years.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ithaca

results.headline: Review: ‘For the Love of Spock,’ a Son’s Tribute to Leonard Nimoy
results.summary_short: Adam Nimoy’s documentary about his father nimbly straddles biography and “Star Trek” valentine, but also recounts the fraught but devoted ties between father and son.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of For the Love of Spock

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Wild Life,’ Island Critters School a Castaway
results.summary_short: This animated film, long on amiability if not complexity, features amusing animal characters learning to collaborate with a shipwrecked Crusoe.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wild Life

results.headline: Review: ‘Transpecos’: At a Dusty Border, a Trek Along a Moral Tightrope
results.summary_short: Greg Kwedar’s first feature focuses on three United States Border Patrol agents at a desolate desert outpost.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transpecos

results.headline: Review: In ‘Other People,’ a Son’s Anxieties Mount as Tragedy Looms
results.summary_short: A deeply personal tale from the writer-director Chris Kelly, the movie follows a gay comedy writer in New York who returns home to care for his mother.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Other People

results.headline: Review: In ‘Landfill Harmonic,’ One Person’s Trash Is a Child’s Violin
results.summary_short: This documentary focuses on a Paraguayan landfill that became the wellspring for a children’s orchestra, which uses instruments assembled from discards.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Landfill Harmonic

results.headline: Review: ‘Come What May,’ an Ode to French Villagers Displaced by War
results.summary_short: Christian Carion’s event-packed World War II film lines up an impressive cast but leans toward the sentimental and schematic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Come What May

results.headline: Review: ‘The Apostate’ Chronicles a Rebellious Catholic
results.summary_short: Federico Veiroj’s wry comedy-drama portrays a frustrated young man who sets out on a quixotic mission to have his baptism records expunged.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Apostate

results.headline: Review: ‘Equal Means Equal’ Asks How Far Women Have Really Come
results.summary_short: Kamala Lopez’s fact-packed documentary features legal experts, ordinary women and feminists like Eleanor Smeal and Gloria Steinem.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Equal Means Equal
